content: Gracias por contestar Gerardo. Si es una cuenta de IMAP. El procedimiento fue cerrar la sesion y reiniciarla nuevamente pero los datos se debieron cargar de forma manual. Puede que haya cambiado alguna configuracion, pero lo desconozco ya que una persona ajena realizo el procedimiento y no logro contactarla por el momento. content:
Hola, Vamos por partes: IMAP Depende de su proveedor de su cuenta, por ejemplo gmail, hotmail, live, etc tienen sus paginas web para ver los correos online, si es un proveedor de correo privado debería contactar con su soporte para saber si tiene esta posibilidad.

Si tiene clientes de correo uno con IMAP y otro con POP3 con la misma cuenta eso es un problema, ya que el cliente POP3 descarga los correos del servidor, pruebe abrir este cliente sin conexión a internet para revisar si están los correos buscados. Saludos

content: I would like to archive emails from my numerous email accounts locally, but with each account in a separate local folder so that they are stored in different locations on my hard drive. Later, I would like to permanently archive a local folder, including removing it from Thunderbird. However, I may need to open such emails again at some point and would then like to import them back into Thunderbird.
creator: cwinkler

content: in the 'copies&folders' pane of each account, you can specify unique folder for the archiving. For the removing and later importing, you can exit thunderbird and use windows file explorer to copy elsewhere, since they are just files. Or, you can use the addon 'importexporttools NG' to do that. just highlight a folder, rightclick and select the importexport option to export mbox. At some future point that you want to read them again, just highlight Local Folders, rightclick and then select the importexport option to import mbox. yes, it's that easy. :)
creator: davidsk

content: thanks for your hint. however, I was referring to this special account called "local folder" which does not have an identity, see attached screenshots. can I have more than one of these?
creator: cwinkler

content:
There is only one Local Folders in Thunderbird, but you can have multiple subfolders. This is because Thunderbird needs a root location. If you click 'account settings' and scroll down left column to Local Folders and look at bottom line, you will see the 'Local Directory' pointer. If you want your local folders to be elsewhere than in the thunderbird profile, it's a simple process:

  1. first, create your root folder for Local Folders. It can be on same drive on another drive.
  2. once done, you can then click the account settings>Local Folders pane and change the Local Directory to point to the one you created. Thunderbird may insist on a restart before using it.
  3. Now, you have local folders separate from thunderbird and set your archive folders in separate folders there.
creator: davidsk

content: See https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-us/thunderbird/addon/localfolder/
creator: sfhowes

content:
Thunderbird only uses one profile. For it to be receiving mail in different profiles would require that you switch between the two. My inference is that one profile is active and there are older messages in the other one. To resolve this, first confirm the active one. You can do that by clicking help>troubleshootinginformation, locate 'Profiles' in left column and then click 'about:profiles' - this will show the name of the active profile, and the inactive profile.

At this point, exit thunderbird and, using windows file explorer, COPY (not move) the folders with missing content from the inactive folder to the active folder <POPaat Mail\Local Folders IMAP accounts are not affected, but if you use POP, the POP account in inactive folder will be at Mail\<POPaccount> folder. Be sure to only copy to Mail\Local Folders for active profile . If ANY copy will overlay an existing folder, RENAME prior to copying. Now, restart thunderbird and you should see the missing data. If desired, you can now copy from these copied folders to their normal folder. TIP: We recommend always using the appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder to copy to new PCs, as that guarantees not experiencing the problem you had. Here are the normal steps: <strong>BACKUP
  1. ensure thunderbird is not running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
RESTORE
  1. ensure thunderbird is installed and NOT running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  4. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content:
In Windows OS > Settings > Personalisation > Colours Please check: 'Choose your mode' Select 'Custom' Make sure both windows mode and the apps mode are both set to 'dark'

In Thunderbird Settings > Composition If you select: 'Use reader's default colours' then it will use the theme colours. The options below for the Text and Background should be greyed out and unused. The prefs:

  • msgcompose.background_color
  • msgcompose.text_color

These are disregarded because you have selected 'Use reader's default colours'.

If you uncheck that option then whatever is set for Text and Background is used, but please note these options are then included in the HTML when you send. So enforced on recipients, although they may have options to override like Thunderbird.

However..... I'm testing this issue in the beta version to see what is going on. I have same settings - use Dark theme and 'Use Reader's default colours' I have not selected 'Use Paragraph format instead of Body Text by default' But if I do select it then it alters results but still not as desired - some areas which have html css code as a 'paragraph' will get black text on white background even if all other areas are applying the dark theme. So that is the weird section you see.

I see all as expected in the 'Message Pane', so that is ok (please note - just for clarity - there is no 'preview' pane and never has been. All emails seen in Message Pane are not previews, they are opened emails.)

Selecting an email which I know has HTML css code applied, so some areas maybe coloured but generally uses black on white. I'm seeing a variety of issues which are not expected. This sounds very similar to the issue you are seeing.

I'm going to create a bug report on this. I'll post a link to it.

creator: ingwe

content:
Ingwe said
Thanks Mapenzi. Yes, this did appear and was set up.

What caused this disappearance of your accounts etc in the main window is a corruption of the central file prefs.js in the Thunderbird profile. When this happens TB renames the damaged prefs.js file in prefs-1.js (sometimes invalidprefs.js) and creates a new virgin prefs.js file with a size of 5 to 7 kB which doesn't contain any account informations. So TB starts like after a first installation and asks to set up an email account. This not very rare issue is most times provoked by TB crashes, PC crashes or power failure. I have seen (and treated) this issue a few dozen times in forums but have never experienced it myself.

Do you have a backup copy of your Thunderbird profile folder? In this case you could copy the prefs.js from the backup and - Thunderbird closed - paste it in your wife's actual profile folder. Did your wife use POP accounts? This would explain why after recreating the account only new messages are downloaded.
creator: Mapenzi

content:
Please check all the following so we can rule them out:

Firewall: Firewall may be controlled by the default on computer or controlled by Anti-Virus software you installed. Please access the Firewall and set up Thunderbird as an allowed program. This ensures the Firewall does not block any required ports. Please confirm you have set up Thunderbird program as allowed.

VPN Check computer for a VPN wihch may have been enabled. Some Anti-Virus products now offer a VPN and in some cases I discovered it had been enabled - user had no idea it existed let alone was enabled. Please confirm, VPN is not enabled. It is switched off.

Please supply the following information so we know the current set up: What OS are you using? What version of Thunderbird are you using ?

AOL has been moving over to the yahoo servers. So I need to know the exact server setting data you are currently using. What are the current server settings you are using: 'Account Settings' > 'Server Settings' for the pop account - post image showing the data on top right.

In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Scroll down to 'MAil and News Accounts' section
  • Copy all the data in that area and paste it into this support question.
  • OR post an image showing all the data.

Passwords: AOL (and Yahoo) have altered what passwords are permited. Your normal password would get you access to your webmail account, but it cannot be used by Thunderbird pop account to access the server. Sorry if I'm telling you everything the tech said, but I need to know current status. I need to know if you have created what AOL call 'an app password' which would be used in third party apps like Thunderbird. Here is a link to some info:

  • https://help.aol.com/articles/Create-and-manage-app-password

If yes, you have generated an 'app password' then I need to know if you did this: In Thunderbird

  • Settings >Privacy & Security
  • Scroll to Passwords section
  • click on 'Saved Passwords
  • Click on 'Show Passwords'
  • Pop account will have two entries: mailbox://account.... and smtp://account....
  • Right click on the mailbox pop line and select 'Edit Password'
  • completely cleared the old data
  • enter the new app password - do make sure it is correct.
  • Do the same for the pop smtp line
  • Click on close

Exit Thunderbird - wait a few moments for background proceses to update Start Thunderbird.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re :I have two installations of Thunderbird with each being on a different bootable partition of the same drive so they never get used simultaneously.

Important information is missing. Are you using a different OS on each bootable partition ? eg: Windows 11 on one and a Linux OS on the other ? Are you using a different version of Thunderbird on each partition? eg: Current Release on one and Current Beta on another ?

Problem when using different versions of Thunderbird: Since version 68 or something like that...there was a change to use dedicated profile per installation. Senario: If one TB version is 128* and it uses profile 'A' and then at a later time another version of TB 144* uses 'A', this now means profile 'A' cannot so easily be used by TB version 128* because it's not automatically backwards compatible.

Therefore, both versions of Thunderbird must always be identical in order to access the same profile.

A different senario occurs when each bootable partition is using a different OS.

re :IMAP but I assume this will allow for messages already downloaded by the first instance and then subsequently downloaded by the second be flagged as unread. This seems trivial but a moderate inconvenience

No. You assume incorrectly. If you have read the email in IMAP 'A' then server will state it is read, so another IMAP 'B' will say what it says on server - it's read - it will not be marked as unread.

The point of IMAP accounts is that you can have as many IMAP accounts as you like accessing same email account but set up on various computers and as all data is stored on server and assuming you have subscribed to see same folders, the IMAP accounts can only display whatever is on server. If you set a star in one imap account, then when you view via another imap account, after the usual synchronisation you will see same email with a star. If you have read an email, then it is marked on server as read, so however you view that email, it will be the same. There is a continual synchronisation of folders when it comes to IMAP accounts.

I would advise you never assume you have an truelly independent copy on your computer and that's because all folders synchronise with same folders on server to show a view of whatever is on server. Anything you do - move, delete, mark, etc is updated to server and when you start Thunderbird, the first thing it does is to synchronise with server. If you delete emails in one IMAP account, then view same account in another IMAP account, it will update and you will see those emails you deleted disappear. Assuming you are downloading full copies of emails, then you can use the Thunderbird copy to create a backup. But do not assume you have a backup just because the imap account is on another drive or computer.

IMAP accounts do not have to be copy pasted, you can newly create it. The only file you may have to copy paste after creating the account is the 'msgFilerRules.dat' file - it's the file that contains all your 'Message Filters' assuming you may have set some up. But, if you have a lot of IMAP accounts then yes, it's probably quicker to copy paste the entire contents of a 'profile name' folder into another 'profile name' folder.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Thanks very much for your reply Toad-Hall! Great info with ample insight.

Well, you actually fixed my issue. Although I was convinced by everything I previously read, which you also touch upon, that post v68 TB shared profiles were no longer an option. As per your noting I made sure to update both versions to 140.4.0esr and sure enough I can now switch between bootable partitions and have regained seamless operation of both TB instances.

I was already using ESR and with the likelyhood that chasing updates to stave off these hiccups may be persistent this is just one more reason to stick with ESR and its not-as-frequent updating.

Just to fill in some blanks -- It is the same Win10 on both partitions and I assumed (crazy me ;-)) that TB would also be automatically kept in sync. I do have all my IMAP accounts set to keep copies on the server for 30 days even though that's not an issue for me as my only mail readers (these two instances on TB) are sharing the same profile and message storage location.

content:
You can test the following CSS code in your userChrome.css file: 

#calendar-event-dialog { min-width: 60em; !important; min-height: 80em !important; }


Note that the userChrome.css file must be moved in a chrome folder to be created in the Thunderbird profile folder. Furthermore open Settings > scroll to the bottom and click Config Editor.... Search for "toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets" and toggle its value from false to true

Furthermore open Settings > scroll to the bottom and click Config Editor.... Search for "toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets" and toggle its value from false to true

I haven't looked at the code, but I suspect that the contents of the editing popup are done as a series of nested tables...perhaps the size of that pane simply can't be adjusted through css?

content:
Well your image is odd. The window called 'Edit Event Test' is clearly a lot larger in width and height, but it's not being used by the content. The toolbar showing 'Save and Close'......'Delete' is chopping off all the options in menu and is badly restricted. The Calendar, Title, Location etc is all restricted in width and should by default fill the width of window. Near the bottom where you have 'Descripion' - that text are is also very restricted. 'Notify attendees' etc options by default wouldbe located at the bottom.

By default in the natural design without any userChrome.css code - all the above expands with window in both height and width. The height and width can be manually expanded by hovering over the bottom right corner to see the cursor change to double headed arrow and using the left click on corner and drag to expand to whatever is required.

I can only assume that you have created code which is messing it up.

I assume the intention is to force the current window to auto open in a larger window than the current default, so you do not have to manually enlarge as described above.

AS far as I can tell the code for items in that window is all set to flex. So you only need to alter the size of the window when it opens.

I used the following and now I can force the Task and Event window to open by default in a larger window and all contents are auto flex to fit anyway, so no need to alter that code. 

#calendar-event-window, #calendar-task-window {   min-width: 63em !important;   min-height: 81em !important; }

creator: @next

content:
re :When I tried to set up my email from my website it keep downloading the emails over and over and over. Doesn't seem to recognize that these emails have already been downloaded?

I'm assuming this account has also been set up as a POP account. Has it been set up to be an independent account with it's own set of folders displayed in the Folder Pane or did you set it up as a deferred account - more commonly known as a Global Account which uses the Local Folders account.

In 'Account Settings' > 'Server Settngs' for the pop website account on right side click on 'Advanced' button and tell me what is selected - OR just upload an jpg image file.

If you have an Anti-Virus or similar product or even a clean up file product like CCleaner or WiseCleaner which are allowed to scan any opened file or delete what it calls temp files then havoc is seen. It is advised that you do not allow any Anti-Virus or cleanup product to scan anything in your Thunderbird profile. Please make sure your thunderbird profile folder is exempt from scanning as we need to be sure there is no interferance.

Assuming you downloaded Thunderbird from the official website:

  • https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/

Then the 'Thunderbird' folder you need to exempt will be in the following location:

  • C://Users/<username>/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird

Pop accounts use a 'popstate.dat' file to record what has been downloaded, so it does not download the same again. If that file is corrupted and maybe a new file is repeatedly being created then Thunderbird has no knowledge of what has been previously downloaded. AV or Cleanup software can cause a problem if they do anything with that file or indeed any file in your profile.

In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Application Basics' - half way - Profile Folder - click on 'Open Folder'

A new window opens showing contents of your profile name folder.

  • Exit Thunderbird now - this is important
  • Click on 'Mail' folder to see list of pop accounts
  • Click on the appropriate pop account for website folder to see contents.

You are looking for the 'popstate.dat' file. You may see more than one - maybe with a number applied. Tell me what you see - maybe post an image.

Please delete any 'popstate.dat' file you see in that account folder. Unfortunately, this will mean you will get another complete download again. But we have to do it.

When you restart Thunderbird - a new 'popstate.dat' file is created and now it does not have any AV or other software scanning or having access to it. Yes, it will do a complete download again, but it should only do it once. Please report back on results.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Thank you for the feedback. We're all volunteers, and you're welcome to help. There are never enough people, as your post indicated, to keep everything current and also to help others in using Thunderbird. It would be a big help if you would post URLs of major error pages that you encountered.
creator: davidsk

content:
Are you referring to the KB articles at https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/products/thunderbird or threads in the Thunderbird section of the support forum https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/thunderbird?show=all

If threads then check the date as they may be old as in for much older version of Thunderbird when it was not under Settings yet. Threads are auto archived and locked after six months so that is an indicator the information may not be up to date depending.

If a KB article is outdated and no longer relevant it is not deleted but marked as as longer maintained and not show up in normal search results. If it is relevant then it can be updated as you can submit an edit to be looked at.

For example this is a old KB article for desktop Firefox https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/Firefox%20cache%20file%20was%20infected%20with%20a%20virus that has been marked This article is no longer maintained, so its content might be out of date. and no longer shows up in normal support.mozilla.org search results.
creator: James
